full.title: Analysis of the Global Warming Potential of Biogenic CO<sub>2</sub> Emission in Life Cycle Assessments.
full.authorString: Liu W, Zhang Z, Xie X, Yu Z, von Gadow K, Xu J, Zhao S, Yang Y.

authorAffiliation.affiliation: School of Natural Resources, West Virginia University, Morgantown, WV 26506, United States.

full.abstractText: Biomass is generally believed to be carbon neutral. However, recent studies have challenged the carbon neutrality hypothesis by introducing metric indicators to assess the global warming potential of biogenic CO<sub>2</sub> (GWP<sub>bio</sub>). In this study we calculated the GWP<sub>bio</sub> factors using a forest growth model and radiative forcing effects with a time horizon of 100 years and applied the factors to five life cycle assessment (LCA) case studies of bioproducts. The forest carbon change was also accounted for in the LCA studies. GWP<sub>bio</sub> factors ranged from 0.13-0.32, indicating that biomass could be an attractive energy resource when compared with fossil fuels. As expected, short rotation and fast-growing biomass plantations produced low GWP<sub>bio</sub>. Long-lived wood products also allowed more regrowth of biomass to be accounted as absorption of the CO<sub>2</sub> emission from biomass combustion. The LCA case studies showed that the total life cycle GHG emissions were closely related to GWP<sub>bio</sub> and energy conversion efficiency. By considering the GWP<sub>bio</sub> factors and the forest carbon change, the production of ethanol and bio-power appeared to have higher GHG emissions than petroleum-derived diesel at the highest GWP<sub>bio</sub>.
full.affiliation: School of Natural Resources, West Virginia University, Morgantown, WV 26506, United States.

abstract: Biomass is generally believed to be carbon neutral. However, recent studies have challenged the carbon neutrality hypothesis by introducing metric indicators to assess the global warming potential of biogenic CO<sub>2</sub> (GWP<sub>bio</sub>). In this study we calculated the GWP<sub>bio</sub> factors using a forest growth model and radiative forcing effects with a time horizon of 100 years and applied the factors to five life cycle assessment (LCA) case studies of bioproducts. The forest carbon change was also accounted for in the LCA studies. GWP<sub>bio</sub> factors ranged from 0.13-0.32, indicating that biomass could be an attractive energy resource when compared with fossil fuels. As expected, short rotation and fast-growing biomass plantations produced low GWP<sub>bio</sub>. Long-lived wood products also allowed more regrowth of biomass to be accounted as absorption of the CO<sub>2</sub> emission from biomass combustion. The LCA case studies showed that the total life cycle GHG emissions were closely related to GWP<sub>bio</sub> and energy conversion efficiency. By considering the GWP<sub>bio</sub> factors and the forest carbon change, the production of ethanol and bio-power appeared to have higher GHG emissions than petroleum-derived diesel at the highest GWP<sub>bio</sub>.
title: Analysis of the Global Warming Potential of Biogenic CO<sub>2</sub> Emission in Life Cycle Assessments.
